Converting a React application with Redux and Apollo to Next.JS

If you have clicked on this blog odds are that you have heard of Next.JS, if not allow me to introduce it. Next.JS is a React framework that is best known for its server side rendering capablities which allows for better search engine optimization (SEO). In short the reason for which we at Unilous among other React developers switch to Next.JS is to aliviate the hastle of SEO in the most effective manner.

Although Next.JS is already built on the shoulders of React, there are still many chalenges which need to be overcome before getting the application up and running. For this guide I will touch on the key changes I had to make when converting my React application with the centralized state management: Redux, and the GraphQL API: Apollo to Next.js.

I highly suggest you finish this tutorial provided by Next.JS before getting started with this guide

For reference this is what your final Next.JS application should look like.

Converting a React application with Redux and Apollo to Next.JS

If you have clicked on this blog odds are that you have heard of Next.JS, if not allow me to introduce it. Next.JS is a React framework that is best known for its server side rendering capablities which allows for better search engine optimization (SEO). In short the reason for which we at Unilous among other React developers switch to Next.JS is to aliviate the hastle of SEO in the most effective manner.

Although Next.JS is already built on the shoulders of React, there are still many chalenges which need to be overcome before getting the application up and running. For this guide I will touch on the key changes I had to make when converting my React application with the centralized state management: Redux, and the GraphQL API: Apollo to Next.js.

I highly suggest you finish this tutorial provided by Next.JS before getting started with this guide

For reference this is what your final Next.JS application should look like.

  1. 1. Update your node environment

    First you must set up the proper node packages so that the application runs as a Next.JS app rather than a React app.

    You will need to replace the following scripts from React

    {reactPackages}

    With the standard Next.JS scripts

    {nextPackages}

  2. 2. Adjusting navigation

    Next.JS routing depends on the file structure whereas React routing was dependant on the BrowserRouter component. This process can be separated into several steps...

    a. Reorganize components

    Next.JS requires a root level folder named pages.

    Within this folder is where all of the routing happens. You can think of the pages folder as the host of your site and the files within the folder are paths with an exception of index.js which will serve as the host page. For more information on routing in Next.JS I reccomend this guide from its official documentation.

    To accomplish this you will need to move all of you root page files excluding your App.js file into a new pages folder. Next I strongly suggest you rename all of your files to follow proper url naming conventions so that you avoid problems with browsers and ensure your url remains readable. In the case that you have dynamic routes you will need to follow this guide from the official Next.JS documentation.

    b. Transform App.js to Layout.js

    The traditional App.js serves to distribute components to all of the pages to ensure they have a uniform appearance. In Next.JS, since all of the pages are independent of each other, that will no longer work.

    Usually in within this App.js file you will contain the BrowserRouter component, the navigation bar or header, and the footer. To get started adjusting this file, rename it to Layout.js. Then remove the BrowserRouter component along with the Route components within it, as they are no longer needed.

    {routerItems}

    In its place leave the other components like the navigation bar and add {'{props.children}'}

    {layout}

    c. Redirect paths

    Once you have your pages folder set up make sure to redirect all paths to other files within the folder as they have been relocated within your application.

  3. 3. Adjusting Redux

    Redux integration to react looks mostly the same throught the whole application. The reducers do not need to be changed in any way outside of relocating them to the root of your project. The store.js on the other hand does recieve two additions to be able to implement Thunk into Redux as middleware.

    First you must implement the following function to connect the middleware to Redux.

    {bindMiddleware}

    Then the bindMiddleware function must be implemented before exporting the store. To do that we replace the applyMiddlware function with bindMiddleware and place the bind middleware inside. Additionally we make the store a fuction to avoid errors later on. The final store variable should look like the following...

    {store}

    This will then affect the way you will need to map dispatch to props requireing the use of the bindActionCreators import from redux. In the end any file that needs to disptach to prople will need to change from this...

    {oldDispatch}

    to something similar to this...

    {newDispatch}

    There will be some more changes needed to get Redux to work but I will address them once we get to the new index.js or _app.js page.

  4. 4. Integrating Apollo

    The integration of Apollo requires minimal changes much like redux. The first change will be to relocate the ApolloClient and everything connected within it to its own apollo.js file, then move that file inside a folder named lib on the root of the app. Once apollo.js is in its new folder, make sure to to export the ApolloClient variable. For the default export you will need to utilize the withApollo import from Next.JS, the final default export will look like the following...

    {apolloExport}

    Additionally in the case that you have have user authentication and rely on a browsers localStorage, you will need to make the folowing change to the way you get your token. From this...

    {oldToken}

    To this...

    {newToken}

    This lack of access to browser utilities as a result of server side routing results in the biggest change to working with Apollo in Next.JS. The same issue with the token will likely occur in other areas of your application depending on how you interact with browser utilities like localStorage. In general I recommend that that you reduce the amount of code that lies inside if(typeof window !== 'undefined') {'{}'}. Additionally you should include an else statement for when that information cannot be recieved so that you coomponent does not render blank coming into the client.

    As a means of dealing with the same issue posed by server side rendering, Next.JS provides the functionality to load data while on render. To do that Next.JS provides the getInitialProps functionality which is ran before the actual React component is rendered. Once that data is fetched it can then be passed as a prop to the same React component. The code would look similar to this...

    {getInitialPropsEx}

    One thing to note is that only files under the pages directory can use getInitialProps so components wont have this option.

    There will be some more changes needed to get Apollo to work but I will address them once we get to the new index.js or _app.js page.

  5. 5. Reformating index.js to _app.js

    The index file is used to connect other top level technologies like Apollo and Redux. Next.JS requires a similar, the file must to be named _app.js and be located inside the pages folder. Since we have already separated the Apollo code into its dedicated file the _app.js file becomes very simple. The _app.js file will now only contain a React component with a getInitialProps attatched to it and a somewhat complicated default export.

    For the React component the props will need to get destructured into the key components {`{ Component, pageProps, store }`}. The component will serve as the App.js itself and we will need to pass he pageProps for its attributes. The Component will only need to be wrapped by the react-redux Provider where the store will be passed as store. The resulting code will look like this...

    {_appRC}

    Unfortunatly you cannot get access to props without directly adding the following getInitialProps. This serves to pass the props to the rest of the pages. The code will look like this...

    {_appGIP}

    The default export for _app.js is far from ordinary as it requires some final additions. The redux store needs to be wrapped around the withRedux wrapper provided by Next.JS. For the Apollo component you must indicate that the application is server side rendered (SSR) like this {`{ssr: true}`}. Finally you stitch together both React and Apollo with the compose function from redux. The final code will look like this...

    {_appDE}

  6. 6. Working with static files

    For static files there are only a few minor changes needed. First the static folder should be moved to the root directory of your applications. In the case that you have any SVGs you will need to move them to the public folder. Now that the static folder is finalized in the root directory all that is left is to update paths leading to it.

    because the SVGs are nnow located under the public folder there will need to be one major change towards accessing th SVGs. Unlike before where you would import SVGs into your application and distribute them as a variable, like so...

    {oldSVG}

    Now you can simply access your SVGs through a route as if your public folder was the host

    {newSVG}

    Next.JS also offers a great feature with files by simply adding a .module to CSS files. This feature serves to better organize the nameing of styles. To learn more about this feature visit this guide from the official Next.JS documentation.
